item.title: Puerto Rico and Virgin Islands
item.description:
This winter break, I went on a 7 day trip in the Carribean. I began (and ended) in Puerto Rico, but visited multiple outlying islands.

I thoroughly enjoyed hiking through El Yunque, a rainforest near San Juan. I got a cool peek of a lone palm tree atop a hill.

We hired a tour guide (Andres from Atabey Tours) who brought us to the national park (El Yunque) as well as a private part of the rainforest, where we were able to swim in a river and stand under a waterfall. Andres was super cool- he hiked the entire way barefoot, picked up trash, and showed us medicinal plants in the rainforest.

The scenery here is best enjoyed from a rope swing.

We stopped for lunch at a crowded restaurant inside the park. These were some wonderful rice and beans! The rice was cooked perfectly- each grain was moist and full without becoming mushy and indistinct.

Our first stop was in St. Thomas, still U.S. territory (praise the 4G). We spent the day at the beach where we swam and did breathing exercises (because why not?)

Check out the view through these trees!

St. Croix was pretty boring to be honest. We ended up enjoying 4G on the ship most of the day, but we did find this groaner of a name.

Antigua (often mentioned along with its neighbor Barbuda) is pronounced ‘Antiga’ by most people in the Carribean. Lots of catamarans floating around the ports (reminds me of the Wookie catamarans in Star Wars…)

There were some awesome views though. That island looks a lot like a crocodile, doesn’t it? Also note all the expensive yachts floating around. There was a definite wealth disparity between most of the towns and some secluded vacation homes.

St. Lucia was probably my favorite island (not counting Puerto Rico). We took a van tour around the entire island basically. Note: In St. Lucia, like Antigua and other former British colonies, people drive on the left!

A landing strip on the island.

A banana grove. The blue bags are to keep bugs and birds away. Fun fact: banana plants (they’re not trees!) only bear one crop of fruit! After that, they’re chopped down and provide nutrients for the new shoots.

We were offered (and politely declined) the opportunity to take a hot mud bath. Instead, we watched from a distance.

A pretty little boat docked in the harbor.

A pelican atop a post.

Here’s the port in Grenada. Colorful rooftops are a favorite of mine.

Back in Puerto Rico, we rented a van and explored Old San Juan. It’s almost like Spain! (at least that’s what my friend who’s been to Spain said…)

I love cobblestone streets (though they make for bumpy rides…)

Old San Juan (as a port city) has two forts. You can easily walk between them and the downtown area (in fact you can see one fort from the other).

There’s a beautiful plain in front of one of the forts. Many kids were flying kits in the wind.

Here’s an artsy photo from inside a tower.

As proof of Puerto Rico being a U.S. territory, check out this Post Office and box!

This place reminds me of China- plenty of old folk playing cards and dominoes in the park.

A tall building downtown.

And that’s it for this time!

Oh wait- bonus weasel…

item.title: Scenes from Last Semester
item.description:
A late afternoon sunset over the neighborhoods north of East Campus in Durham.

Pink and orange streaks in the sky above the Biddle Music building on Duke East Campus, Durham.

One of the Keohane quad bridges, stretching over some red leaves below.

Over the semester, my facult-in-residence family, Prof. Hwansoo Kim and Sumi Loudon Kim, hosted many ‘Snack Attacks’ over at their apartment. (I’m still searching for a Mango Lassi recipe that rivals theirs…) Over Thanksgiving Break, they kindly had students over for brunch, which included some playtime with their cats!

As part of House Council, I helped organize some well-received food events, such as ‘Dessert Night’. Check out these oreo and cookie cupcakes!

My dorm at sunset. Looks a lot like the silhouette of a castle, huh?

McClendon tower. Many long and late nights were spent working on CompSci assignments here, fueled by coffee and wafers from Bella Union.

This year a new video game center opened up on campus, complete with 10 PC’s, a Wii, and multiple PS4s and Xbox Ones. Over Thanksgiving break, Austin and I attempted to finish the story of Borderlands: The Presequel.

Paul’s Pelikan M400 Souveran fountain pen in white tortoise with a Broad nib. Man, what a pen! Looks beautiful, fits just right into your hand, and -of course- is smooth beyond belief.

One thing I like to do is build mechanical keyboards. I start by thinking about what size board I want- full size with arrow keys and numpad or perhaps something smaller and more portable. My latest build is what’s called a ‘Planck’. It’s a 4 x 12 grid of unstaggered keys which is super compact and perfect for tucking into a backpack. After deciding on a layout, I choose my switches. You can get clicky ones (that may drive friends and co-workers crazy), silent and super light switches designed for gaming, and everything in between. These switches are then arranged in a matrix with diodes and wires, which are then connected to a Teensy microcontroller that is flashed with the actual firmware. This entire setup fits inside a case I laser cut out of acrylic (complete with engraved Stormtrooper helmet on the bottom). The last step involves adding keycaps and testing the board out! Of course, I forgot to mention the hours of hardware debugging with multimeter in hand, checking every single connection to find the source of the inevitable bugs (‘I’ key returning ‘J’s for example). But it’s well worth it in the end!

I’ve spent countless hours loitering around the Innovation Co-Lab, 3D printing and laser cutting all sorts of things. They recently got 20 or more new Ultimaker 2s- some of the sweetest 3D printers I’ve ever used.

These things run for a couple thousand each…

The suburbs are a beautiful place, telephone wires and all. (The blue sky helps too)

Walking back to my dorm with the sun in the sky.

A lasercut topo map made by my outdoorsy friend Addison.

The sun peeking through some trees between Edens and Keohane quads.

‘Friendsgiving’ in the dorm this year. Great food and (minimal) food burning.

Actually one of the best turkeys I’ve ever had! We cooked it ourselves.

Some violet flowers outside.

An orange dusk over the East Campus tennis courts.

That’s it for 2015! See you in a bit.

item.title: Zhongshan | China 15
item.description:
Zhongshan (中山) is a city in the south of China. It’s a 45 minute bullet train (高铁) ride from Guangzhou’s main train station.

The downtown area is clustered with electronics shops and all sorts of inflatable advertisements. Go beyond the downtown area and you can find thick mazes of small gray houses.

I also visited the nearby Sun Yat-Sen High School. This places looks unreal! It’s like the backdrop of a Japanese high school drama or anime.

There’s a random boat in the pond!

Lots and lots of green here.

The sign at the front entrance.

There’s quite a lot of lotus ponds nearby. The place we visited also offered Chinese bananas. They’re still yellow, but a lot chubbier than those found in U.S. supermarkets. The flavor was similar, but had a much fuller, tangy taste that reminded me of papaya almost.
